content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, and appropriate congressional committees. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like appropriate congressional committees, foreign air carrier, and intelligence community. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like intelligence community, secured area, and Security Identification Display Area as per specific sections of relevant laws and regulations. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like Security Identification Display Area and sterile area according to specific sections of federal regulations. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, must submit a cost and feasibility study to Congress and the Comptroller General regarding the impact of implementing secure doors with card, pin entry, or biometric technology at various airports within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The impact of implementing secure doors with card, pin entry, or biometric technology at Category I, II, III, IV, and X airports includes surveillance video recording, advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, explosives trace detection swabbing, and advanced imaging technology. The study will include information on employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening of employees accessing secured areas, including costs for technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, explosives trace detection swabbing, advanced imaging technology, and x-ray bag screening technology. The study will assess the costs and effectiveness of implementing security features at category I, II, III, IV, and X airports that have already screened 100% of employees accessing secured areas. This includes evaluating costs for establishing entry and exit points and comparing costs to the Federal Government and airports/aviation community. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct an assessment upon completion of the study. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the study assessing security features at airports and the aviation community, reporting to the Committee on Homeland Security within 60 days of receiving the study. The Comptroller General of the United States will report to relevant committees on the results of the review of airport security features within 60 days of receiving the study. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be established in consultation with air carriers and airport operators. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards for aviation security to address insider threats, collaborating with stakeholders and reporting to congressional committees within specified timeframes. The Administrator will report to congressional committees on the assessment of insider threats to aviation security within 30 days. Airport operators must submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access credentials within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access credentials to enhance security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied the credential. Additionally, airport operators must include a screening notice in applications for access to the Security Identification Display Area. The Administrator will require airport operators to include a screening notice in applications for access to the Security Identification Display Area, informing applicants that they may be screened at any time while accessing, working in, or leaving the area. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to swiftly detect and address insider threats to aviation security. The Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats to aviation security and how to mitigate them. This includes leveraging resources from the Department of Homeland Security and the intelligence community. The Administrator will utilize resources from the Department of Homeland Security and the intelligence community to educate Administration personnel on insider threats to aviation security and improve mitigation efforts. Playbook operations will be targeted and strategic, focusing on enhancing security effectiveness. Covert testing of employee inspection operations will be conducted by the Administrator. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness. Results are shared with airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers for improvement. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness. Results are shared with airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers for improvement, along with recommendations and technical assistance for conducting their own employee inspections. The Administrator is required to submit an annual report on the frequency of these tests to congressional committees for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and shares results with stakeholders for improvement. A national database of individuals with revoked airport badges will be established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Annual reports on employee inspection operations will be submitted to congressional committees for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Aviation Security Advisory Committee will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges and set up reporting mechanisms for airlines and airport operators to submit data and access the database. The Aviation Security Advisory Committee will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges. The process will allow individuals to correct mistaken entries and have their names removed from the database. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, foreign carriers, and airport operators. Additionally, there are provisions for information technology security. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of security controls for Administration IT systems at airports within 90 days of this Act. No additional funds are authorized for these requirements. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 25, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
